In addition, the results (not tabulated) hold when the regressions are run either with firms listed only on NYSE or on the NASDAQ, suggesting that the results are not driven by micro-structure factors.42 To further investigate whether the results are caused by the inventory component of the spread, I regress both price and return volatility on LSTR and the control variables of the extended model. Results (not tabulated) indicate that both volatilities are negatively associated with labor strength (although the significance of this result varies across specifications).43 This would suggest the inventory costs would be lower for those firms and, therefore, do not drive the spread results.44  

The coefficients on the control variables generally have the expected signs. NASDAQ and smaller firms have larger spreads. 45 As expected, LogPrice is positive in the undeflated specifications and negative in the deflated ones. The four measures of risk are positively correlated with higher spreads and are generally significant. The effect of outside monitoring is ambiguous. Consistent with the idea of firms disclosing more good than bad news, future sales growth is associated with smaller spreads. However, contemporaneous returns do not seem to affect the spreads (at least when BM is included in the regression).46 ROA is positive, perhaps because of a correlation between ROA and intangible assets or industry maturity. Spreads are smaller when managers are more sensitive to the cost of equity, either because they personally own more of the firm (although the coefficient is only significant in the deflated specifications), or because they plan a SEO. This result is consistent with managers disclosing more information to reduce the adverse selection problem in these cases. As expected, higher volumes are associated with smaller spreads.  

When LSTR is interacted with measure of the current or future economic situation (ROA and Expect) in the extended model, LSTR remains significant. The interaction between Expect and LSTR is never significant while the interaction with ROA is negatively significant in the PERC regression but insignificant in the RAW one. This suggests the disclosure policy is not affected by the current or expected state-of-the-world but rather is determined by the long-term value of the parameters.  

Finally, I consider two additional measures of information asymmetry as dependent variables: PIN and trading volume. In the PIN regression, LSTR is consistently positive in all the specifications similar to the ones used with RAW and PERC. For example, Column 4 of Table 4 indicates that the corrected t-statistic is 5.35 in the extended model (7.14 in the parsimonious model, untabulated). The economic magnitude is such that increasing LSTR by one standard deviation increases PIN by approximately $5\%$ of the median PIN. In other words, increasing labor strength reduces the likelihood that trades are carried out for liquidity purpose and increases the likelihood they are based on private information. When I use the log of the trading volume as a dependent variable, LSTR is negative in all specifications (with t-statistics between -4.37 and -25.35 depending on the specification). The economic magnitude is such that increasing LSTR by one standard deviation decreases trading volume by approximately $6\%$ of the average trading volume. This results is consistent with the “no trade theorem' (see Milgrom and Stokey (1982)) that suggests trade will be reduced in the presence of higher information asymmetry.  

To summarize, empirical results show a positive relation between labor strength and spreads. Spreads are composed of three components. Different tests rule out the possibility this relation is due to micro-structure factors or to higher inventory costs (idiosyncratic risk). This indicates the empirical relation is due to the last component, information asymmetry. The asymmetry is the difference between what is known by the most informed traders but not disclosed to uninformed traders. This relation is robust to control for growth option, risk, managerial incentives and numerous other factors, including firm and industry fixed effects. In other words, the relation is not due to a greater intrinsic uncertainty about the corporation performance. This interpretation is reinforced by a positive relation of labor strength with the probability of informed trading (PIN) and a negative one with volume.  

### 4.2 Analyst coverage  

The results from the analyst coverage regressions are presented in Table 5. 1 present results using OLS specification (column 1) and a count-data (negative binomial) technique (e.g., Rock, Sedo and Willenborg (2000), column 2). The standard errors are robust and allow for clustering of observations by year but results are qualitatively similar when observations are clustered by industry (results not tabulated). They are also robust to the use of a panel specification (random effects). Column 3 reports results of the 2SLS procedure where LogPrice and ROA are used as instruments. The standard errors are estimated through a robust GMM procedure. The first-stage F-statistic in the 2SLS is equal to 200 and a Hansen J test fails to reject the orthogonality condition, suggesting that the instruments are adequate.47 Finally, I perform a two-step procedure. In a first step, I estimate the predicted value of the spreads using LogPrice and ROA as instruments. In the second step, I use a negative binomial regression to estimate the effect of LSTR on analyst coverage. I boot-strap the system 100 times to obtain consistent standard errors in the second step. This procedure is analogous to the usual 2SLS but uses a count-data technique in the second step instead of the standard OLS. Average coefficients and $95\%$ confidence intervals are reported in brackets in column 4 of Table 5.  

All models indicate a significantly negative relation between labor strength and analyst coverage. The t-statistics for LSTR are respectively -5.43, -4.16 and -6.40 in columns 1 to $3.R$ and Lint are positive and usually significant. Both the statistical and the economic significance of the results (not tabulated) typically increases when I log LSTR or I use the log of the number of analysts (plus one since the log of zero would not be defined if the firm is not covered at all) as the dependent variable. Substituting PERC for RA W gives qualitatively similar results (not tabulated). The variable is also significant at less than $1\%$ level in column 4 of Table 5. Results (not reported) still hold in the four specifications at a confidence level of less than the $1\%$ when the only control variables are size and the spread (deflated or not), suggesting that the results are not driven by the introduction of irrelevant variables. The effect on analyst coverage is such that an increase by one standard deviation of LSTR would lead to a decrease of approximately $18\%$ of the median coverage. The economic magnitude materially increases when LSTR is logged.48 Analyst coverage is increasing in size, price volatility, future economic prospects, issuance of security and outside bond rating but decreasing in complexity (number of segments), market concentration and spreads. These results are generally consistent with prior literature.  

To summarize, empirical results establish a negative link between labor strength and analyst coverage. Analyst coverage has been used by prior literature as a direct summary measure for information asymmetry. This result is consistent with the result found in section 4.1 and reinforces its interpretation based on an informational explanation.  

## V Conclusion and Extension  

This study examines whether the existence of strong organized labor is associated with  higher information asymmetry between informed  and uninformed  market participants. Prior literature suggests that reducing information asymmetry weakens management's position in collective bargaining. A possible theoretical explanation is that strong labor increases the ambiguity concerning managerial objectives. This ambiguity gives management a valuable option to credibly manipulate expectations and in turn an incentive to protect its information asymmetry to preserve this option. The empirical results are generally consistent with this hypothesis and show a positive relation between labor strength and spreads and the probability of informed trading as well as a negative one between labor strength and both trading volume and analyst coverage.
